facts.fact_text: The Japanese yen steadied around 156.8 per dollar on Friday.

evidences.evidence_text: The Japanese yen steadied around 156.8 per dollar on Friday

facts.fact_text: The Japanese yen was set to lose more than 1% for the week.

evidences.evidence_text: but was still set to lose more than 1% for the week

facts.fact_text: The yen had rallied as much as 4.5% in late January amid speculation of a US-Japan joint currency intervention but has since surrendered more than half of those gains.

evidences.evidence_text: The yen had rallied as much as 4.5% in late January amid speculation of a US-Japan joint currency intervention but has since surrendered more than half of those gains.

claims.claim_text: Expectations that Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi will win voter backing for increased spending and potential tax cuts, raising concerns over Japan’s fiscal outlook.

evidences.evidence_text: The currency came under pressure amid expectations that Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi will win voter backing for increased spending and potential tax cuts, raising concerns over Japan’s fiscal outlook.

claims.claim_text: Japan’s Q4 GDP is expected to rebound after a sharp contraction in the previous quarter.

evidences.evidence_text: Investors are also awaiting Japan’s Q4 GDP report next week, which is expected to rebound after a sharp contraction in the previous quarter.

claims.claim_text: A weak yen could benefit exporters.
claims.author: Takaichi

evidences.evidence_text: Takaichi recently noted that a weak yen could benefit exporters, later clarifying that her comments aimed to promote an economy resilient to currency swings.

links.source_ref: Increased spending and potential tax cuts

evidence.evidence_text: The currency came under pressure amid expectations that Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi will win voter backing for increased spending and potential tax cuts, raising concerns over Japan’s fiscal outlook.

links.source_ref: Uncertainty over how the government would fund its ambitious plans and offset potential revenue losses

evidence.evidence_text: Uncertainty over how the government would fund its ambitious plans and offset potential revenue losses weighed on markets.
Takaichi recently noted that a weak yen could benefit exporters, later clarifying that her comments aimed to promote an economy resilient to currency swings.
